reviewText: Funny and touching, fine acting, great cast. I found this truly enjoyable. I selected it because I could view it free (Prime) and I wanted to watch something before I went to sleep. I thought it might be a sort of a throw-away if I fell asleep while watching. But it grabbed me from the beginning with characters you wanted to learn more about. I also thought it might be a little smarmy or maybe even a little too rough, based on reviews, but I found it to be touching without going overboard and, though the old man is a bit salty, nothing he said or did was shocking. Maybe you wouldn't want to explain a couple of things to very young kids but for kids of about the same age as the young hero, I didn't see anything that raised my hackles. There are many worse movies with young protagonists. If they've got a grandfather or uncle who is sometimes a bit saltier than the norm, they've already been exposed to worse. And if they're going to public school, they've been exposed to much worse.

reviewText: Perhaps more complex than it might appear with the juxtaposition of characters and emotions. An end to life and the beginning of understanding the responsibilities in life. One reviewer noted that this is not for children and I agree. There is minimal violence but I would suggest parental guidance.The storyline encompasses multiple relationships. Poignant? That it is. What is the true meaning  of  'hero?' There is no need for a definition. Unfortunately, human behavior and characteristics aren't so easily defined. Recommended for both the cast and storyline!

reviewText: This is a charming little movie set in 1959, when life was simpler and everybody liked Ike.  Great characters:  There's the kid who wants to climb a neighborhood tower about to be dismantled to see what nobody else can see; his father, who didn't serve in WWII and is considered a coward by some;  the super-patriotic next-door neighbor who did serve, suffers from shell shock (PTSD) and gets drunk regularly and shoots off his guns; the garrulous, agnostic old man dying of cancer who's trying to help the kid climb the tower in return for getting a gun to kill himself with.  Even the secondary characters are sketched beautifully, and the acting is virtually flawless.  The movie is basically about what real courage means, and who has it.I had a little problem with John Hurt, who played the dying old guy brilliantly except that his British accent kept bleeding through.  But that's a minor quibble.  It's well worth the time spent watching it.  I had an uncle who was seriously screwed up by WWII, so it was easy for me to relate.
summary: A family movie about the meaning of courage

reviewText: Kids say the word "s***" a couple of times in the beginning, but don't be a phony priss, akin to HEIDE DOW (see her little "review" below), and not watch the movie.  Grow up, Ms. Dow! It's about BOYS coming of age,(and most likely, today's parents use worse language in the home).  A HERO'S CLIMB, is both enlightening and entertaining.  Not only do characters in the film learn a life's lesson, but so does the audience.  I thoroughly enjoyed it.  HIGHLY RECOMMEND for boys ranging in age from 8 to adult.
